page.title: 04PAGHAM HARBOUR
page.content:
At Pagham Harbour we saw a small island 100 metres off the shore. It was about 150 metres long and at one end there was a little hill built up of silted sand. At first the entrance to the harbour was not visible, but nearer the sea we saw the entrance with water gushing out very fast.
Pagham Harbour has changed over the years. Because the beach is mostly made of sand, the sea has changed the shape of the shoreline and harbour. The harbour has silted up, forming large banks of sand which make it almost impossible for a boat to enter the harbour. The entrance was deliberately blocked in 1875, but this was washed away in a storm in 1910. At one time Pagham Harbour was the 9th busiest port in the country. Now only a small boat can get in.
